reviewText: I -- myself -- was in highschool (or Vietnam) when the show that had these five-minute segmentsas part of a network program called HOUSEPARTY originally aired."HOUSEPARTY" started out as a radio program in 1945, and ran through 1952.From there [1952] it ran (in Black and White) until 1966's color programs.The show ended in 1969... when I marched off to War.I -- DO -- recall the "Kids Say The Darndest Things" segments, but have no recollection of the restof the show's content. You CAN get a taste of the entire show, if you're interested, and the OTHERprogram Art did:People Are Funny (16 Episodes on 3 Discs).The program -- as the T-I-T-L-E implies -- was directed to HOUSE-wives. The format was "old-school",and, of no interest to school-age childrent although a five-minute segment of the program WAS childen[aged 4 to 12].The majority of the children were under ten, because, let's face it "Kids [DO!] Say The Darndest Things[!]"(unless they are old enough to BE trying to BE funny).So, the two-dozen segments are chapter stopped. The best part -- to me -- was SEEING the vintage toysand bicyles and games the kids got paid with. Being "sexist" the girls get dolls and girlie stuff, while theboys got train-sets and such. Their SCHOOLS got opaque-projectors/TVs/stereo record (or tape )players.Mister Linkletter does the opening wrap-around, and another one half-way through; which makes me wonderif, originally, these TIME/LIFE programs were, one-hour programs that were re-packaged as double programs.I advise that the programs available: Volume 1; 2; & 3 are only identifiable by the different cover art.Also, it's MUCH, MUCH cheaper to buy the titles, seperately.I also would advise, like any OTHER v-e-r-y - l-o-n-g "loop" of short --similar--- program-segments, it's bestNOT to sit on your, ugh!, CHAIR for two -- v-e-r-y - l-o-n-g-- hours unless you really NEED a nap. I don't meanto be unkind.The volumous collection of segments are like a GOOD book before going to bed... sometimes too much of agood thing is just...TOO MUCH.I really liked it...but won't watch them again for a few months -- at my age [I'm 65] -- until I'm 66... and won'tr-e-m-e-m-b-e-r what I saw a few months earlier.
summary: These are a few dozen 5-minute excerpts from the CBS 1960s' program 'HOUSEPARTY'.
Title: N/A

reviewText: They don't make shows like this much anymore and more's the pity, kids see the world with a ruthless no-nonsense clarity and a total lack of tact about how they express it, especially with kindly old Art providing just the right questions. Thee appear to come from the 1960s primarily, and although not quite the knee-slappers of the 1950s it's still a great fun ride. The order went through fine and the DVD arrived ahead of schedule, so all is well with the seller.

reviewText: I chose this rating because it shows the innocent and honesty of a generation of children . Everyone should see this and enjoy the beauty of real innocence before sale phones and violent tv shows and games.
summary: The best of art link letters kids say the darndest things

reviewText: The year is 1968, the show is ART LINKLETTER'S HOUSE PARTY, and 'housewives' everywhere tuned in every afternoon to watch their favorite segment of that show called "Kids Say The Darndest Things".If the above introduction to this review bothers your political correctness you may have some problems with this dated show. Girls are given seperate toys from the boys and have different expectations. Minorities are limited to a few Asian kids, Art & the audience laugh at one boy's bowl-haircut "Your Mom cuts your hair!". You will cringe when two seperate clips have Art asking the kids "Who would you rather get spanked by?", one child replies "My grandmother, because by Dad & Mon use a belt". That does bring an 'oh-boy' on Art's face but he moves on.I did find the first 30 minutes very amusing, but then the remaining 90 minutes became routine with some bright moments. I found myself working on projects while listening to the show as a distraction.I seem to remember better B&W; clips from Art's earlier shows on other retrospective programs. Maybe Art is saving those for other volumes (a sticker indicates this is volume 1), but I feel no urge to see more. This is more than enough.One un-expected high spot is the close-ups of the 1968 toys given as prizes! A two foot Mary Poppin's Doll for the girls would bring a good price on eBay today. The other toys brought back memories for me.This best-of DVD is formatted as one 2 hour clip show with a new introduction by Art. There are some chapters to find the clips.This show is in color, the old tapes are still in fairly good shape although the picture is soft.I do wonder, now, what the entire "House Party" show was like as I only remember this segment.
summary: Not the B&W show, but segments from 1968's HOUSE PARTY.

reviewText: Doesn't matter what age or era, kids really do say the darndest things.  This was a fav program of mine when I was a kid.  As with other shows of it's era, it's a historical marker for the sexism of it's time...even down to the prizes they give to girls vs boys.  Almost an anthropological study.  Or, don't go that deep and just laugh.
